awd_titl_txt: Asymptotic Problems with Boundary Effect in Kinetic Theory
awd_abstract_narration:
Kinetic theory describes the dynamics of a large number of particles, such as flows of air particles passing an airfoil, or neutrons' collisions in a nuclear reactor. In a statistical manner, the kinetic description bridges the micro-scale modeling of motion of particles by Newtonian mechanics and the macro-scale modeling by continuum fluid mechanics. This research project aims to develop novel mathematical methods to quantitatively characterize these multi-scale models. The investigation focuses on the motion of rarefied gas, neutrons, electrons, and ions, in spatially bounded regions under the influence of the surrounding environment. Its applications range from high-tech fields like semi-conductors or nuclear fusion, to daily-life devices like water sprays or fluorescent lamps.

Specifically, this project concentrates on the hydrodynamic limit of the Boltzmann equation or transport equation, i.e. how the solution varies asymptotically when a small parameter, either the Knudsen number or the Strouhal number, approaches zero. In bounded domains, kinetic boundary corrections (i.e. boundary layers), play a crucial role. The investigator intends to justify the validity of the asymptotic approximation in the presence of singular boundary layers. Moreover, the initial-boundary interactions and nonlinear effects are taken into consideration. To tackle the non-standard asymptotic expansions, the investigator seeks to develop general theories of geometric correction in boundary layers, rescaled remainder estimates, Milne regularity analysis, non-local energy methods, and boundary layers decomposition. These techniques can be further applied to Vlasov systems and magnetohydrodynamical (MHD) equations. Also, the rigorous derivations of fractional diffusion and stochastic diffusion are involved.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The systems with a large number of particles are very common in our daily life (the air in a room or the water around a ship), and in science and engineering (aircraft design, nuclear power plant). There are many, many small particles moving nonstop in such systems and colliding with each other. To describe the dynamics of such systems is a significant topic in both theory and practice.

There are two approaches to characterize the evolution of many-particle systems. Naively, we tend to track the position and velocity of each particles at any moment, which is the so-called microscopic description, including Newton?s laws, kinetic theory, etc. While this approach is theoretically sound, it is practically non-viable, not only due to the quantum effects (the position and velocity cannot be measured accurately simultaneously) but also owing to the extremely large number (approximately million-billion-billion) of particles in the system. On the other hand, an approximate but simpler approach was proposed to only focus on the observable quantities like temperature or pressure. This is the so-called macroscopic description, including the fluid mechanics, thermodynamics, etc.

Our research focuses on studying the relation between these two approaches: one is accurate but very difficult and the other one is crude but simple. We would like to provide quantitative description of the effectiveness to use the macroscopic approaches and determine when it fails.

To be more precise, we intend to justify that the solution to kinetic equation, will converge to that of fluid or thermodynamic equations, when a small parameter, the Knudsen number, which characterizes the inverse of collision frequency, shrinks to zero.

In this project, we rigorously justified this convergence when the physical domain is bounded, which means the particles are confined in a small box with boundaries. We proved that the difference of solutions under these two types of descriptions is proportional to the Knudsen number. This indicates that in the dense gas or fluid (the air near earth or water), it suffices to consider the crude models which is much easier and economic. In contrast, in the thin or dilute gas (air in the high altitude for aircrafts), we have to resort to the accurate models to get the correct answer.

In addition, we captured the abnormal behavior of such convergence near the physical boundary. In this thin region, the macroscopic description fails and we must rely on the so-called kinetic boundary layers to fully describe the dynamics. It is mathematically challenging since the solution may vary dramatically in a extremely short distance. Our major contribution is to develop an effective method to depict such phenomena and rigorously characterize the solvability and dynamics of boundary layer equations.

Our results builds solid foundation for the simulation of many-particle systems in bounded domains. It also justifies the validity of multi-scale methods in the computational problems of kinetic models.
